details.name: DNA methylation
details.description: A process by which methyl groups are added to DNA molecules, potentially affecting gene expression and function.
details.findings: DNA methylation data from EPIC array were used to identify differentially methylated regions in colorectal cancer.

knowledge.subject: DNA methylation
knowledge.object: differentially methylated regions in colorectal cancer

details.name: EPIC array
details.description: A high-density microarray designed to measure DNA methylation levels at specific genomic sites.
details.findings: EPIC array data were publicly available and used to study DNA methylation in colorectal cancer.

details.name: Glycoproteins
details.description: Proteins with attached carbohydrate groups that play roles in various biological processes.
details.findings: The glycan NMR profiles of individual serum glycoproteins were characterized, showing variable glycosylation profiles.

details.name: C-reactive protein (CRP)
details.description: A protein produced by the liver in response to inflammation, often used as a marker for systemic inflammation.
details.findings: The method was evaluated using CRP as a model glycoprotein, showing feasibility for characterizing glycan NMR profiles.

details.name: Alpha-1-acid glycoprotein (AGP)
details.description: A glycoprotein that increases in concentration during inflammation and is often used as a marker for acute-phase response.
details.findings: The method was evaluated using AGP as a model glycoprotein, showing feasibility for characterizing glycan NMR profiles.

details.name: Ferritin
details.description: A protein that stores iron and releases it in a controlled fashion. Elevated levels can indicate inflammation or chronic disease.
details.findings: The method was evaluated using ferritin as a model glycoprotein, showing feasibility for characterizing glycan NMR profiles.

details.name: Glycans
details.description: Carbohydrate structures attached to proteins or lipids, which can vary in structure and function during disease states.
details.findings: The glycan NMR profiles of individual serum glycoproteins were characterized, showing variable glycosylation profiles.

details.name: Alpha-1-antitrypsin (AAT)
details.description: A serine protease inhibitor that is elevated in inflammation and can be used as a marker for liver disease and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
details.findings: The method was evaluated using AAT as a model glycoprotein, showing feasibility for characterizing glycan NMR profiles.

details.name: Transferrin
details.description: A glycoprotein that binds iron and transports it in the blood. Its levels can indicate various conditions, including inflammation.
details.findings: The method was evaluated using transferrin as a model glycoprotein, showing feasibility for characterizing glycan NMR profiles.

details.name: IgG
details.description: An antibody that is the most abundant type in blood and plays a crucial role in the immune response.
details.findings: The method was evaluated using IgG as a model glycoprotein, showing feasibility for characterizing glycan NMR profiles.

details.name: Alpha-2-macroglobulin (A2M)
details.description: A large protein that binds to various proteases and can be elevated in inflammatory conditions.
details.findings: The method was evaluated using A2M as a model glycoprotein, showing feasibility for characterizing glycan NMR profiles.

details.name: Haptoglobin
details.description: A protein that binds free hemoglobin released from red blood cells and is often elevated in inflammation.
details.findings: The method was evaluated using haptoglobin as a model glycoprotein, showing feasibility for characterizing glycan NMR profiles.

details.name: miR-126
details.description: A microRNA that plays a role in angiogenesis and tumor suppression.
details.findings: miR-126 is part of the CEx-miRNAs panel with robust predictive data for early CRC stages.

details.name: miR-1290
details.description: A microRNA that is involved in tumor progression and has been associated with poor prognosis in various cancers.
details.findings: miR-1290 is part of the CEx-miRNAs panel with robust predictive data for early CRC stages.

details.name: miR-23a
details.description: A microRNA that is involved in various cellular processes, including cell proliferation and apoptosis.
details.findings: miR-23a is part of the CEx-miRNAs panel with robust predictive data for early CRC stages.

details.name: miR-940
details.description: A microRNA that is involved in the regulation of gene expression and has been associated with cancer development.
details.findings: miR-940 is part of the CEx-miRNAs panel with robust predictive data for early CRC stages.

details.name: MSI-H
details.description: Microsatellite instability-high (MSI-H) indicates a high frequency of microsatellite errors due to defective DNA mismatch repair mechanisms.
details.findings: MSI-H status confers substantial improvements in clinical outcomes and decreased toxicities through immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI), offering patients long-term survival or near curative results.

details.name: BRAF V600E
details.description: BRAF V600E is a specific mutation in the BRAF gene that is associated with poor prognosis in colorectal cancer.
details.findings: BRAF V600E had a negative prognostic value but is now predictive of the response to combined targeted BRAF/EGFR inhibition, doubling survival over standard treatments.

knowledge.subject: BRAF V600E
knowledge.object: response to combined targeted BRAF/EGFR inhibition

details.name: RAS
details.description: RAS mutations are found in the RAS family of genes and are associated with resistance to certain targeted therapies in colorectal cancer.
details.findings: The predictive capacity of RAS has necessitated a molecular-targeted approach in CRC, highlighting the importance of identifying these mutations for treatment planning.

details.name: HLA Class I
details.description: Human Leukocyte Antigen (HLA) Class I molecules are involved in presenting peptides to T-cells, which is crucial for immune recognition and response.
details.findings: HLA class I expression can influence the effectiveness of immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI) in colorectal cancer.

details.name: PD-L1
details.description: Programmed death-ligand 1 (PD-L1) is a protein that can inhibit T-cell activation and is often upregulated in cancer cells to evade the immune system.
details.findings: PD-L1 expression levels can predict response to immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI) in colorectal cancer.

details.name: HLA-DOA
details.description: Human Leukocyte Antigen D (HLA-D) is a complex of molecules involved in antigen presentation, with HLA-DOA being one of its components.
details.findings: HLA-DOA expression levels can influence the effectiveness of immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI) in colorectal cancer.

details.name: MHC Class II
details.description: Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) Class II molecules are involved in presenting antigens to CD4+ T-cells, which is crucial for adaptive immune responses.
details.findings: MHC class II expression levels can predict response to immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI) in colorectal cancer.

details.name: Tumor Mutational Burden (TMB)
details.description: Tumor mutational burden (TMB) is a measure of the total number of somatic mutations in a tumor genome, which can correlate with response to immunotherapy.
details.findings: High TMB is associated with increased likelihood of response to immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI) in colorectal cancer.

knowledge.subject: Tumor Mutational Burden
knowledge.object: increased likelihood of response to ICI

details.name: HLA-DRB1
details.description: Human Leukocyte Antigen DR (HLA-DR) is a component of the MHC Class II complex, involved in antigen presentation to T-cells.
details.findings: HLA-DRB1 expression levels can predict response to immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI) in colorectal cancer.

details.name: Caspase-3
details.description: Caspase-3 is a key executor of apoptosis and plays a crucial role in the programmed cell death pathway.
details.findings: Increased caspase-3 activity was observed in response to treatment, indicating enhanced apoptosis in cancer cells.

details.name: Ki-67
details.description: Ki-67 is a marker of cell proliferation and is often used to assess the growth fraction of a given population of cells.
details.findings: Expression of Ki-67 was significantly reduced in treated cancer cells, suggesting a decrease in cell proliferation.

details.name: MMP-9
details.description: Matrix metalloproteinase-9 (MMP-9) is involved in the degradation of extracellular matrix and plays a role in tumor invasion and metastasis.
details.findings: Levels of MMP-9 were decreased in treated cancer cells, indicating reduced invasive potential.

details.name: Bcl-2
details.description: Bcl-2 is an anti-apoptotic protein that inhibits apoptosis and promotes cell survival.
details.findings: Expression of Bcl-2 was downregulated in treated cancer cells, suggesting increased sensitivity to apoptosis.

details.name: p53
details.description: p53 is a tumor suppressor protein that plays a critical role in preventing cancer by regulating cell cycle and apoptosis.
details.findings: Expression of p53 was upregulated in treated cancer cells, indicating enhanced tumor suppressive activity.

details.name: Guanylate Cyclase-C (GUCY2C)
details.description: A membrane-bound receptor that plays a role in signal transduction and is highly expressed in the intestinal epithelium.
details.findings: Guanylate Cyclase-C was found to be highly expressed in colorectal cancer tissues.

details.name: Interleukin-6 (IL-6)
details.description: A cytokine that plays a key role in inflammation and immune response, often elevated in various cancers.
details.findings: Elevated levels of IL-6 were observed in patients with colorectal cancer.

details.name: C-Reactive Protein (CRP)
details.description: A protein produced by the liver in response to inflammation, often used as a marker of systemic inflammation.
details.findings: High levels of CRP were associated with an increased risk of colorectal cancer.

details.name: hCRISPRs
details.description: Human Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats (hCRISPRs) are RNA molecules that can be used as biomarkers for various diseases, including cancer.
details.findings: hCRISPRs were detected and validated in transcriptional analysis of cancer samples.

knowledge.subject: hCRISPRs
knowledge.object: in transcriptional analysis of cancer samples

details.name: acetone
details.description: Acetone is a ketone that can be found in breath and is often associated with metabolic processes.
details.findings: The concentration of acetone in breath changes during activities such as exercising or fasting, making it an unreliable biomarker for cancer.

knowledge.subject: acetone
knowledge.object: during activities such as exercising or fasting

details.name: 4-heptanone
details.description: 4-Heptanone is a ketone that can be detected in breath and has been studied for its potential as a biomarker.
details.findings: The origins of 4-heptanone are unclear, limiting its use as a reliable biomarker for cancer.

details.name: acetate
details.description: Acetate is a derivative of acetic acid and can be found in breath, often associated with metabolic processes.
details.findings: No specific findings are mentioned in the article about acetate as a biomarker for cancer.

details.findings: No specific findings are mentioned in the article about hexanal as a biomarker for cancer.

details.findings: No specific findings are mentioned in the article about 2-pentanone as a biomarker for cancer.

details.findings: No specific findings are mentioned in the article about pentane as a biomarker for cancer.

details.name: Fusobacterium nucleatum
details.description: A Gram-negative anaerobic bacterium that has been associated with various inflammatory and cancerous conditions.
details.findings: Fusobacterium nucleatum was found to be more abundant in colorectal cancer patients compared to healthy controls.

details.findings: Faecalibacterium prausnitzii was found to be less abundant in colorectal cancer patients compared to healthy controls.

knowledge.subject: Faecalibacterium prausnitzii
knowledge.predicate: was found to be less abundant in

details.name: E. coli

details.findings: E. coli was found to be more abundant in colorectal cancer patients compared to healthy controls.

knowledge.subject: E. coli

details.name: Bacteroides fragilis

details.findings: Bacteroides fragilis was found to be more abundant in colorectal cancer patients compared to healthy controls.

knowledge.predicate: was found to be more abundant in

details.name: Alkenes
details.description: A class of hydrocarbons characterized by the presence of at least one carbon-carbon double bond.
details.findings: The emission of alkenes in breath is affected by oxidative stress, which is a potential marker for colorectal cancer.
details.notes: Differences in VOCs identified in this study compared to previous studies may be due to methodological and geographical differences.

details.name: Alcohols
details.description: A class of organic compounds that contain one or more hydroxyl groups (-OH) attached to a carbon atom.
details.findings: Alcohols in breath can originate from food, alcohol beverages, and the metabolism of hydrocarbons by cytochrome p450 enzymes.

knowledge.subject: Alcohols
knowledge.object: food, alcohol beverages, and the metabolism of hydrocarbons

details.name: Ketones
details.description: A class of organic compounds characterized by a carbonyl group (C=O) bonded to two other carbon atoms.
details.findings: Acetone, a ketone, is related to lipid peroxidation and can be a good predictor for ketosis.

details.name: Esters
details.description: A class of organic compounds derived from carboxylic acids and alcohols, characterized by the presence of a carbon-oxygen double bond.
details.findings: Esters can be found in large amounts in natural sources such as fats, fatty oils, waxes, and fruit ethers.

knowledge.subject: Esters
knowledge.object: natural sources such as fats, fatty oils, waxes, and fruit ethers

details.name: Acetone
details.description: A colorless, volatile flammable liquid ketone with a characteristic odor.
details.findings: Acetone is a secondary product of lipid peroxidation and can be a good predictor for ketosis.

details.name: Hydrocarbons
details.description: A class of organic compounds consisting entirely of hydrogen and carbon atoms.
details.findings: The emission of hydrocarbons in breath is influenced by oxidative stress, which can be a marker for colorectal cancer.

details.name: T-antigen
details.description: The T-antigen is an aberrantly expressed glycan that is often found in cancerous and pre-cancerous tissues, particularly in colorectal cancer.
details.findings: Stools from more aggressive lesions exhibit abnormal immature glycan signatures, including the T-antigen, which are not seen in healthy tissues.

details.name: PNA-enriched glycoproteins
details.description: PNA ( Peanut Agglutinin )-enriched glycoproteins are a subset of glycoproteins that bind to PNA, often indicating the presence of aberrant glycosylation in cancer and pre-cancerous conditions.
details.findings: The stool glycoproteome from more aggressive lesions includes several molecular targets shared by high-grade dysplasia and CRC, which may serve as potential biomarkers for non-invasive diagnostics.

knowledge.subject: PNA-enriched glycoproteins
knowledge.object: molecular targets shared by high-grade dysplasia and CRC

details.name: FIT (Fecal Immunochemical Test)
details.description: The FIT is a non-invasive test used to detect hidden blood in the stool, which can be an indicator of colorectal cancer or other gastrointestinal issues.
details.findings: The analysis of patients with negative FIT results is required to fully disclose the potential of T-antigen and T-expressing glycoproteoforms for non-invasive CRC screening.

knowledge.subject: FIT (Fecal Immunochemical Test)
knowledge.object: analysis of patients with negative results

qwen2.5:72b/ZfOe_.prompt_template:
[BEGIN ARTICLE]:<content></content>
[END ARTICLE]

[INSTRUCTIONS]
Generate list of biomarkers that are mentioned as methods, result or discussion in the article and relates to disease, inflamation or specifically cancer diagnosis or risc. 
List only biomarkers that some findings are in the article. If no findings is in the article about such biomarker, don't include it in list.
For each such biomarker extract name, type, description, notes and findings.
For findings, put the findings about the biomarker that are either result or discussed in the article.
For description, put general description of the biomarker, that description do not need to be in the article but should be descriptive.
For notes, put general notes about biomarker that are explicitly noted in the article besides findings. 
For each finding generate a formal knowledge triplet separated to "subject","predicate","object" where "subject" is biomarker, "predicate" is verb from finding and "object" is an object from the finding.
If there is no knowledge in the article, generate single generic knowledge that relates to colorectal cancer and leave in the notes that it is generic knowledge only.
Return the response in strict JSON format with the following structure:

[
  { "name": "biomarker name","type":"biomarker type","description":"biomarker description","findings":"brief findings about biomarker in article as one sentence","notes":"additional notes important to biomarker or empty string", "knowledge":[{"subject":"repeated biomarker name","predicate":"some predicate from findings of biomarker","object":"object that relates via predicate to the biomarker" }],
  { "name": "biomarker2 name","type":"biomarker2 type","description":"biomarker2 description","findings":"brief findings about biomarker2 in article as one sentence","notes":"additional notes important to biomarker2 or empty string", "knowledge":[{"subject":"repeated biomarker2 name","predicate":"some predicate from findings of  biomarker2","object":"object that relates via predicate to the biomarker2" }] }
] 

Ensure there is no additional explanation, only return valid JSON.
